channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Soldier Is Missing. What Comes Next?
item.description: The military first used drones, armed checkpoints and raids on suspected militant strongholds to try to find Pfc. Bowe Bergdahl, according to classified military logs given to WikiLeaks.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Lesson for P.O.W.’s Father: Men Sometimes Do Come Back
item.description: Robert Bergdahl fought in Washington for his son’s release from the Taliban for five years. On Saturday, President Obama said Bowe Bergdahl was coming home.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH BUMILLER and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: President Obama greeted Robert and Jani Bergdahl, the parents of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, at the White House on Saturday.

item.title: Before Syrian Suicide Blast, a Quiet Life in the Suburbs
item.description: An American man who a militant group said detonated 16 tons of explosives was remembered in the Florida subdivision where he grew up for his love of basketball.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES and EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS
item.media:description: Moner Abusalha, at left, with a man said to be a Maldivian suicide bomber.

item.title: Listening Post: In Obama’s Speeches, a Shifting Tone on Terror
item.description: After five and a half years and dozens of addresses, the trail of President Obama’s foreign policy pronouncements has grown muddier.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama before delivering a commencement address at West Point on Wednesday.

item.title: In Ukraine War, Kremlin Leaves No Fingerprints
item.description: Eastern Ukraine is becoming the setting of a subtle game in which Russian freelancers, not soldiers, are shaping events.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alexander Borodai, left, in Donetsk, Ukraine, where separatists are defying the government.

item.title: As Ties With China Unravel, U.S. Companies Head to Mexico
item.description: With costs rising rapidly in China, American manufacturers are looking to Mexico with an eagerness not seen since the early years of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flambeau opened its manufacturing facility in Saltillo, Mexico, instead of China.

item.title: Bowe Bergdahl, American Soldier, Freed by Taliban in Prisoner Trade
item.description: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the lone American prisoner of war from the Afghan conflict, has been released in exchange for five Taliban prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in a video released in 2010. Sergeant Bergdahl was freed on Saturday in a prisoner swap with the Taliban.

item.title: Britain’s New Immigrants, From Romania and Bulgaria, Face Hostilities
item.description: When the European Union extended full employment rights to Romanians and Bulgarians, some politicians here warned that there would be a flood of desperate immigrants. The influx did not arrive but strained relations did.
item.dc:creator: By KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: A Romanian Orthodox service in Luton, north of London. More than 100,000 Romanians were living in Britain in 2012.

item.title: American Businesses in China Feel Heat of a Cyberdispute
item.description: Following the Justice Department’s indictment of five members of the Chinese Army on economic cyberespionage charges, Chinese government agencies are reviewing their use of IBM servers — an example of the growing tensions.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: The People’s Bank of China and other agencies are reviewing their use of IBM servers.

item.title: Roadside Bombing in Afghanistan Kills 12 Civilians
item.description: No one immediately claimed responsibility for the attack, which took place in the Giro district of Ghazni Province and killed civilians headed to a wedding, an official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Taliban Attack Military Posts in Pakistan
item.description: The attacks, which killed one soldier and set off a gun battle that left 16 militants dead, were the latest along the volatile and porous Afghanistan-Pakistan border.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Mutharika, Ex-Leader’s Kin, Named Winner of Malawi Vote
item.description: The country’s election commission declared Peter Mutharika, the brother of a president who died in 2012, the winner of a presidential election marred by unrest and complaints.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: The opposition leader Peter Mutharika, waving at left with his deputy, Saulos Chilima, after taking the oath of office.

item.title: China Accuses U.S. and Japan of Incitement
item.description: A senior Chinese military official’s remarks followed speeches by Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel and Japan’s prime minister faulting China for maritime disputes with its neighbors.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Baptist Missionary Sentenced to Life in Hard Labor by North Korea
item.description: The South Korean Baptist missionary was accused of trying to build underground churches in North Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing: Bombing Thwarted, Israeli Military Says
item.description: Israeli troops on Friday detained a Palestinian man who was wearing a belt packed with explosives at a West Bank intersection that has been the site of previous attacks, Israeli military officials said.
item.dc:creator: By IRIT PAZNER GARSHOWITZ

item.title: Iran Hackers Dangle a Familiar Name to Fish for Data
item.description: Hackers seeking information about Washington’s elite posed as John R. Bolton, a former American ambassador to the United Nations, to friend online users through social media.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: John R. Bolton, a former ambassador turned cybertarget.

item.title: Norway Moves In to Guard Oil Rig From Greenpeace
item.description: Oil drillers are moving farther north as the Arctic ice retreats, opening areas that were previously inaccessible and as fields to the south are depleted.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Sway in Asia Is Imperiled as China Challenges Alliances
item.description: As Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel visited Singapore, the Obama administration’s Asia policy appeared to be turning into a street fight, with the United States playing referee.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel in Singapore on Friday.

item.title: In Spanish Riots, Anguish of Those Recovery Forgot
item.description: Four nights of demonstrations in Spain’s tourism capital have highlighted the country’s persistent social tensions and belied signs of relief from years of austerity.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: A riot police officer stopped a demonstrator in Barcelona who protested the eviction of squatters from Can Vies, a warehouse.

item.title: Suicide Bomber Is Identified as a Florida Man
item.description: An American who blew himself up in a suicide attack in Syria was identified by officials as Moner Mohammad Abusalha, who has lived in Fort Pierce and Vero Beach.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI, ERIC SCHMITT and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: A photo circulated by jihadists was said to show Moner Mohammad Abusalha, the bomber.

item.title: World Briefing: Terrorism Suspects Arrested in Spain
item.description: The Interior Ministry said Friday that the police had arrested six members of a group who were accused of recruiting militants to fight in Libya and Mali.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: One Man, Two Wives and Many Accepted Forms of Violence in Pakistan
item.description: An uncle and two cousins were among those accused of beating to death a pregnant woman who married against her family’s wishes.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Mohammad Iqbal said he was also beaten by the crowd of men. “When Farzana was killed, I fell on her body,” he said of his wife. “But they pulled me off and started beating her body and her face with their shoes.”

item.title: World Briefing: Detained Factory Workers in Cambodia Are Released
item.description: A Cambodian court on Friday convicted almost two dozen factory workers and human rights activists for instigating violence during protests early this year but then released them under suspended sentences.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: 2 Kidnapped Women Freed in Malaysia
item.description: A Chinese tourist and a Filipino worker have been rescued nearly two months after they were abducted from a resort off Borneo, Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: South Korean Sentenced in North Korea
item.description: North Korea sentenced a South Korean missionary to life with hard labor on Friday after convicting him of espionage and setting up an underground church.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
